title: Psychological Safety
content: Psychological safety means team members feel safe to take interpersonal risks—speak up, question, admit confusion, challenge ideas—without fear of punishment or humiliation. It's not about comfort; it's about enabling the candor teams need to perform.

scenario.story: A team has two members with concerns about a plan. One works with a leader who thanks people for raising issues. That member speaks up. The other works with a leader who responds to concerns with irritation. That member stays silent. The spoken concern reveals a flaw; the unspoken one doesn't—until it causes a problem.

options.A: Both members should speak up regardless of leader behavior
options.B: Leader responses directly determine whether team members voice concerns
options.C: The silent member was at fault

scenario.explanation: People rationally assess the risk of speaking up. Leaders who respond poorly teach silence. Leaders who respond well teach candor. Psychological safety is created by leader behavior, not declarations.
